unnormalised: Cybersecurity firm "DesiDefenders" discovers a new ransomware strain dubbed "LootmaarLock" targeting small businesses. The malware, reportedly disguised as a "free Diwali wallpaper" email attachment, encrypts crucial files and demands a ransom of ₹50,000 for decryption. Experts at IIT Delhi are now working overtime – fueled by copious amounts of chai and samosas – to crack the encryption.

unnormalised: According to sources, LootmaarLock exploits vulnerabilities in outdated Windows XP systems (yes, some people still use those!). The ransomware has already impacted several small sweet shops in Surat, causing widespread panic as they can't access their billing systems. One shop owner, Mr. Patel, lamented, "My jalebi recipe is encrypted! How will I make jalebis for Diwali?"

That 'Diwali bumper offer' email could be a digital diya of doom," he quipped, adding that using strong passwords like "password123" is practically inviting cybercriminals for a chai pe charcha over your data.

unnormalised: The CERT-In (Indian Computer Emergency Response Team) has issued an advisory urging businesses to back up their data and implement robust security measures. "Prevention is better than cure, especially when the 'cure' involves paying ransom to some digital dacoits," the advisory stated. So, stay safe, folks! And remember, even your friendly neighborhood chaiwala might be a victim of LootmaarLock!
